I won't gloss over that there are still continued issues within areas of the organization, but upper leadership and most mid-leadership listens to the needs of their staff and works to improve things for staff. job_title: Community Support Specialist in Sedalia, MO
pros: Working with the clients and gaining experience in the mental health field.
cons:
I wanted to share some concerns about the lack of diversity and the language that is prevalent in the smaller clinics of Burrell. As an African American woman, I feel that the smaller clinics need training regarding the language they use. Although it does not seem like the staff in clinic mean to be provocative or racist, they have implicit biases that say otherwise. I worked for Burrell for six months and my experiences with the clients were great. It was so great working with the clients that I ignored the unprofessionalism of staff at the Sedalia clinic. 
There have been racial undertones in their conversations and right out divisive talk. This has made me very uncomfortable working for Burrell. Since I am not from Missouri, I am not accustomed to many of the states values. One thing that is universal is professionalism and I have not gotten that from my short time here. 
Although I had a great experience working with the clients and gaining knowledge to further my career, I did not feel welcomed when I first started my career with Burrell. There was isolation. 
There is a lack of diversity and inclusiveness in the Sedalia Clinic. I believe all clinics should have sensitivity and cultural training so that staff are well equipped to handle racism and crude comments. Language is big part of what we  Community Support Specialist do. 
I appreciate your time and thank you for reading my concerns. I hope there is a change in the future!

pros:
Steady, Dependable Hours - I came to this job after 15+ years in retail, so having a regular, steady schedule is fabulous.  My hours are reliable and while overtime is kept to a controlled minimum, I am able to get it occasionally which is very appreciated.  We have paid holiday time, and accrue vacation and sick leave at a competitive rate.

Co-workers - This is probably the best part of my job.  I work at Gardine, where there are only a small handful of employees, so having a crew that works well together is imperative!  But even though our house crew is small, the company has a much larger crew, so whenever I've needed time off for vacation, or even the one time I had to call off for an emergency, someone has always been willing to help out with covering hours.  I have not worked here for very long, but there have already been at least three occasions I can think of where someone has gotten sick or hurt, and I've watched the team pull together to help take care of things till that employee was able to come back to work.  It's really great to have a reliable team where we have each other's backs.

Communication - We have weekly staff meetings so that everyone is on the same page, giving a sense of solidarity that is especially important when dealing with the clients we work with.  We also send out daily written logs to all of our staff so that we can keep abreast of everything that has happened every day.

Opportunities for Growth - Any time a position has opened up throughout the company, it is first offered to employees who are already here.  I am comfortable in my current position but feel confident that if I ever want to move up, I will be able to do so.

Work Worth Doing - Working with mental health patients is a special challenge, but definitely something that is worth all the hard work our staff puts into each and every day.  

Appreciation - Nothing makes a job happier than feeling like you're appreciated!  I've worked under two different supervisors and both have taken the time on a few occasions to just shoot me a quick email thanking me.  It's a small, simple gesture that really made my day!  Our coordinator recently sent a mass email thanking all of us who stepped up to fill in for a sick employee - so nice to know that when our team works together, it's noticed and appreciated!
cons:
Pay - The pay isn't great, just a little bit above minimum wage.  I am not sure when/how/if raises are offered. 

Training - I felt REALLY unprepared the first few times I had to do something that did not happen every single night (instructed to perform a fire drill, taking a client to the hospital, etc.) but to be fair, those are things that you can't exactly get hands-on experience with in a standard evening of training!  My supervisors have always taken the time to go over situations with me when needed, though, so that I would be ready for the next event!

review_title: I have been working for Burrell for almost 10 years.
pros: I love the work I do at Burrell in helping others.  Burrell provides me with a stable job which includes year round work with full benefits, affordable insurance, holidays off and vacation time.  I also love the flexibility I have had with my position and setting my hours.  My direct supervisors have always been outstanding and sensitive in providing a respectable work environment and any personal needs when they have occurred.  I love that I work for a company that over the last 10 years has done a great job passing audits because they are consistently careful to monitor employee work throughout the year.  This gives me yet another sense of security and relief that the company I’m working for is also stable.  I’m happy that our new CEO is looking at some of the concerns that Burrell has struggled with over the years and has already been making small changes to improve this.  I’m hopeful that these changes will continue to improve the overall challenges that have existed for so long.
cons: Some of the challenges that have existed have been that at times staff/departments that do not do the job have been placed in a position to create rules and even forms without the knowledge of doing the job (lack of communication between departments).  At times, including currently, there are unrealistic productivity requirements and also expectations to earn bonuses.  There was a requirement that salaried employees had to clock in and out which has been dismissed and corrected (Thanks CJ ).  Raises are not consistently offered and at times there have been raises given to newer staff due to upgrading market salaries while long term staff have been excluded from receiving a raise.  Those who struggle with ongoing changes in your position might not like working for Burrell.  Burrell is always moving forward and changing to improve, this has shown to be difficult for some personality types.

review_title: It partially depends on the people you're purported to support.
job_title: Direct Support Specialist in Springfield, MO
pros: Management is usually pretty flexible and nice. Since you're never at the office there's not really "office politics" to worry about. Pay and benefits are pretty good, and you get compensated (usually $.40/mile) for gas if you're transporting clients. It's entry-level so you have a good shot getting employed here if you meet minimum requirements.
cons:
People say this job is "fulfilling" and that you make a difference but I... really don't feel it. At all.

I think it partially depends on who you're helping. With higher-functioning clients, you keep thinking they can reach the goals set for themselves, and then you wind up disappointed (and, depending on who you're working with, possibly verbally abused) on an almost constant basis. I cry at least once a week after work (and often during). Rather than feeling more compassion for people with disabilities, I'm just tired, terribly stressed, sometimes just plain unsympathetic, and occasionally even resentful. 

I also pay probably around $200/month for gas and have to get my oil changed every 5-6 weeks (read: I drive almost 3000 miles per month). I don't think Burrell reimburses enough for all that. 

Not to mention, I have a Psychology BS and I applied for a position asking for a 4-year degree and I was interviewed for this entry-level job instead. As a direct result of my employment here I'm learning web development so I can change careers entirely. 4 years of college and $10k in loans - completely wasted. Wish I'd have known sooner. (But that's my personal problem.)
